structured.description: A Camera class that handles projection and view transformation matrices for rendering 3D graphics. The class has an abstract method calculateProjectionMatrix that returns a Matrix4f object, and two concrete subclasses, ViewCamera and OrthographicCamera, that extend the Camera class and implement their own calculateProjectionMatrix method. The Camera class also has methods for calculating the view matrix based on the transform and translation of the camera, as well as an adjustToViewport method to set the projection matrix to fit within a specified viewport size.

items.description: Is an abstract class that represents a camera in a 3D environment. It has various methods and fields related to camera calculations, transformations, and viewport adjustments. The class also includes an abstract method for calculating the projection matrix, which can be used to transform 3D objects into 2D space.
items.name: Camera

items.description: Retrieves the view projection matrix, which is used to transform 3D points from world space to screen space. If the matrix has changed or is null, it calculates and stores the view matrix locally.

returns.description: a Matrix4f object containing the view projection matrix.

usage.code:
Camera camera = new Camera();
	Matrix4f viewProjectionMat4 = camera.getViewProjection(); // returns the current projection matrix if available or calculates it from scratch

items.name: getViewProjection

items.description: Calculates a view matrix for a camera, combining rotation and translation of the camera with the projection matrix.

returns.description: a matrix representing the combined effects of camera rotation and translation.

usage.description: In this example, MyCamera is a subclass of the Camera class and overrides the calculateViewMatrix method to use the transform data to create the view matrix. The projection matrix is passed as an argument to the superclass constructor, which is then stored in the projection variable for later use. The transform variable is also set to the given transform object. Finally, the calculateViewMatrix method uses the transform data to calculate the camera position and creates a new Matrix4f with the calculated translation vector.

items.name: calculateViewMatrix

items.description: Generates a matrix representing the translation of a camera positioned in 3D space.

returns.description: a 4x4 transformation matrix representing the camera's translation vector in the world space.

usage.description: In this example, a new instance of the Camera class is created and assigned to the variable `camera`. The `getTranslationMatrix()` method is then called on the camera object and the resulting matrix is assigned to the variable `translationMat`. Finally, the `Vector3f` object representing the position of the camera is obtained from the `transform.getTransformedPos().mul(-1)` method and used to initialize a new Matrix4f object using the `initTranslation()` method.

items.name: getTranslationMatrix

items.description: Retrieves a reference to the `transform` object, which is used for geometric transformations.

returns.description: a reference to an instance of the `Transform` class.

items.name: getTransform

items.description: Is an abstract class that serves as a base for other classes in the Camera package. It has a method called getAsMatrix4() which returns a Matrix4f object, but no implementation details are provided. The purpose of this class seems to be to provide a common interface for various camera-related classes in the package, allowing them to share a common structure and methods.
items.name: CameraStruct

structured.description: A `Texture` class that loads and manages textures for an OpenGL application. The code uses various packages such as `GL11`, `GL14`, and `Util` to create and manage textures, bind them to specific texture slots, and set texture parameters like filtering, wrapping, and texture min/mag filter. The `loadTexture()` method loads a texture from a file using `ImageIO` and creates a byte buffer representation of it. The `bind()` method binds the texture to a specific texture slot, and the `getID()` method returns the ID of the bound texture.

items.description: Defines a class for managing textures in an OpenGL environment. The class provides methods for binding and unbinding textures, as well as loading textures from files. The loadTexture method takes a file path as an argument and returns the ID of the loaded texture.
items.name: Texture

items.description: 0) binds an object to a specified method invocation site.
items.name: bind

items.description: Sets the active texture slot to a specific index (0-31) and binds a texture to that slot using the `glBindTexture()` method.

params.name: samplerSlot
params.description: 0-based index of a texture slot that specifies which texture to bind to the current texture unit.

usage.code:
Texture texture = new Texture("example.png");
texture.bind(1);

items.name: bind

items.description: Returns the instance variable `id`.

returns.description: the integer value of the `id` field.

usage.description: The code above shows an example on how to get the id of a texture object from the texture class.

items.name: getID

items.description: Loads a texture from a file, converts it to a GL texture and stores it in an integer ID.

params.name: fileName
params.description: name of the texture file to be loaded and read by the `loadTexture()` method.

returns.description: an integer ID representing a loaded texture.

items.name: loadTexture

structured.description: A 3D camera class `Camera3D` that inherits from the `Camera` class. The class has various methods for calculating and updating the camera's projection matrix, as well as handling user input for moving the camera. The code uses the `GL11` package for rendering and the `Keyboard` and `Mouse` packages for handling keyboard and mouse input. The code also defines a `CameraStruct3D` class that represents the camera's state, including its position, orientation, and field of view.

items.description: Defines a camera class that inherits from the `Camera` class and has additional features such as adjusting to the viewport size, calculating the projection matrix, and processing input events. The class also includes a `processInput` method that handles mouse and keyboard input events and moves the camera accordingly.
items.name: Camera3D

items.description: Takes a `CameraStruct` object as input and returns the projection matrix in form of a `Matrix4f` object.

params.name: data
params.description: 3D camera's properties, such as its position, orientation, and field of view, which are used to calculate the projection matrix.

returns.description: a `Matrix4f` object representing the projection matrix as specified by the input `CameraStruct`.

items.name: calculateProjectionMatrix

items.description: Adjusts the camera's projection and view matrices to fit within the specified viewport dimensions. It also sets the viewport dimensions using `GL11.glViewport()`.

params.name: width
params.description: width of the viewport in pixels.

params.name: height
params.description: 2D viewport size of the graphical representation of the scene, which is used to calculate the appropriate projection matrix and view matrix for the camera's rendering.

items.name: adjustToViewport

items.description: Is a sub-class of the Camera Struct that contains additional attributes and methods to handle 3D camera calculations, such as fov, aspect, zNear, and zFar. It also provides a method for getting the matrix representation of the camera's projection.
items.name: CameraStruct3D

items.description: Initializes a matrix representing a perspective projection with the specified field of view (fov), aspect ratio, near and far distances.

returns.description: a Matrix4f object representing a perspective projection matrix.

items.name: getAsMatrix4

items.description: Rotates the object based on mouse input and key presses, moving it along the forward direction of its rotation.

params.name: dt
params.description: 3D game time step, which is used to calculate the movement of the object based on keyboard input.

params.name: speed
params.description: 3D movement speed of the entity being controlled by the code, which is multiplied by the time interval `dt` to determine the distance traveled during each iteration of the function.

params.name: sens
params.description: sensitivity of the mouse input, which determines how much the character will move when the mouse is moved.

items.name: processInput

items.description: Modifies the position of an object by adding a directional vector multiplied by a scalar value to its current position.

params.name: dir
params.description: 3D direction in which to move the object, with the magnitude of the movement specified by the `amt` parameter.

params.name: amt
params.description: amount of movement along the specified direction, which is added to the current position of the transform.

items.name: move

structured.description: A `Shader` class that loads and manages shaders for rendering 3D graphics using OpenGL. The code loads shaders from files, compiles and links them to create a program, and provides methods for setting uniform values and matrix transformations. The code also includes utility functions for reading shader source code from files and validating the program.

items.description: Is designed to load and manage shaders for an OpenGL context. It provides functions for binding a program, getting the location of uniform and uniform matrix functions, and loading vertex and fragment shaders. The class also validates the program after loading the shaders.
items.name: Shader

items.description: GlUseProgram(program) to associate a program object with the current GL context.

usage.description: In this example, a new instance of the `Shader` class is created with the name "myShader". Then, the `bind()` method is called on this instance, which binds the shader to the OpenGL context.

items.name: bind

items.description: Returns the value of the `program` field.

returns.description: an integer representing the value of the `program` field.

usage.description: In the above code, we first load a shader by calling the static method loadShader with the name of the shader file, and then we get the program ID associated with the loaded shader using the method getProgram() in our Shader class. The value returned is an integer representing the program ID that can be used to interact with the shader through OpenGL calls.

items.name: getProgram

items.description: Is a method that sets a uniform float value(s) for a given shader program location, based on the length of the input array of float values.

params.name: name
params.description: name of the uniform location for which the values are being set.

params.name: vals
params.description:
0 or more floating-point values that will be passed to the corresponding glUniform() method to set the uniform value of the same name as the function.

* Length: 1 to 4
* Content: A sequence of floating-point values

The length of `vals` determines the number of arguments passed to the corresponding GL uniform function (GL20.glUniform1f, GL20.glUniform2f, GL20.glUniform3f, or GL20.glUniform4f).

items.name: uniformf

items.description: Unloads a 4x4 uniform matrix from an OpenGL context to a flipped buffer.

params.name: name
params.description: 3D uniform matrix that is to be loaded and applied as a transformation to the graphics object.

params.name: mat
params.description: 4x4 matrix to be uniformed.

items.name: unifromMat4

items.description: Is a part of the Java API for OpenGL, and it returns the uniform location of a named uniform in an OpenGL program.

params.name: name
params.description: name of the uniform to locate.

returns.description: an integer representing the location of a uniform in a program.

usage.code:
Shader myShader = Shader.loadShader("MyShader");
int uniformLocation = myShader.getLoaction("uniformName")

items.name: getLoaction

items.description: Loads a shader program from a file and creates a new shader object that represents it.

params.name: filename
params.description: name of a shader file to be loaded.

returns.description: a new instance of `Shader` object that represents a shader program created by combining a vertex shader and a fragment shader.

items.name: loadShader

items.description: Loads a shader program into memory and attaches it to a program handle.

params.name: target
params.description: type of shader to be created, which can be either a fragment shader or a vertex shader.

params.name: src
params.description: 3D graphics shader source code that will be compiled and linked to create the final shader program.

params.name: program
params.description: 3D graphics program that will be used to link the loaded shader with, allowing for the creation of a fully functional graphics program.

items.name: loadShader

items.description: Validates a program by checking its link and validation statuses, printing any error messages if they exist, and exiting the program with an error code if there are issues.

params.name: program
params.description: 3D program to be validated and linked, and is passed through the `glLinkProgram()` and `glValidateProgram()` functions for validation and linking.

items.name: validateProgram

items.description: Reads the contents of a given text file and returns its raw string value.

params.name: file
params.description: file to read and return its text content.

returns.description: a string containing the contents of the specified file.

items.name: getText

structured.description: A `Transform` class that handles transformations in 3D space. It has several methods for rotating and translating objects in 3D space, as well as a `getTransformation()` method that returns a matrix representation of the transformation. The class also has an `update()` method that updates the transformation matrix based on the position, rotation, and scale of the object. Additionally, it has a `setParent()` method for setting the parent transform, and a `getTransformedPos()` and `getTransformedRot()` methods for obtaining the transformed position and rotation of the object.

items.description: Is an extension of the Math package, allowing for rotations and scale changes in 3D space. It has several public methods such as update() to update the transform matrix, rotate() and lookAt() to change the orientation, and getTransformedPos() and getTransformedRot() to return transformed positions and rotations respectively. Additionally, it has properties like pos, rot, and scale that can be modified, and a parent field that can link this transform to another one in a hierarchy.
items.name: Transform

items.description: Updates an object's position, rotation, and scale based on its previous values or initializes them if not provided.
items.name: update

items.description: Multiplies a quaternion representing a rotation axis by an angle and normalizes the result, returning a new quaternion representing the rotated orientation.

params.name: axis
params.description: 3D rotation axis around which the rotation will be performed.

params.name: angle
params.description: 3D rotation angle of the object around the specified `axis`.

items.name: rotate

items.description: Computes the rotation required to face a specified point while maintaining a specific direction perpendicular to the plane of the point. The rotation is returned as a `Quaternion` object.

params.name: point
params.description: 3D position of an object that the `lookAt()` method should rotate around.

params.name: up
params.description: 3D direction perpendicular to the look-at point, which is used to calculate the rotation necessary for the camera to face that direction.

usage.code:
Transform transform = new Transform();
transform.lookAt(new Vector3f(0, 10, 0), new Vector3f(0, 1, 0));
usage.description: This code creates a new instance of the Transform class and then uses the lookAt method to set the rotation of the transform object to face in the direction of the point (0, 10, 0) with the up vector being (0, 1, 0).

items.name: lookAt

items.description: Computes a rotation quaternion that looks at a specified point while orienting along a supplied up vector.

params.name: point
params.description: 3D position from which to look at the scene.

params.name: up
params.description: 3D direction that the look-at rotation should be applied to, relative to the position of the object being rotated.

returns.description: a quaternion representing the rotation needed to look at a point in the environment from a specific position and orientation.

items.name: getLookAtRotation

items.description: Checks if an object's properties have changed from their previous values, returning `true` if any change was detected and `false` otherwise.

returns.description: a boolean indicating whether any of the object's properties have changed.

usage.code:
Transform transform = new Transform(); // creating an instance of the class Transform and initializing it with a position, rotation and scale 
transform.hasChanged(); // returns false because all values are equal to their original value
transform.pos.x = 1; // updating a position x coordinate
transform.hasChanged(); // returns true because only the x coordinate of the position has been updated

items.name: hasChanged

items.description: Computes the transformation matrix for an object based on its position, rotation, and scale. It takes the position, rotation, and scale values as input and returns the transformed matrix as output.

returns.description: a matrix representation of a transformation consisting of translation, rotation, and scaling.

items.name: getTransformation

items.description: Retrieves and returns the transformation matrix of its parent node in the scene graph, taking into account changes made to the parent node's transformation.

returns.description: a `Matrix4f` representation of the transformation matrix of the parent node.

usage.description: In this example, the method getParentMatrix is called on an instance of Transform named "myTransform" within the scope of a class named MyClass. The returned Matrix4f is then used to perform transformations on the myTransform object.

items.name: getParentMatrix

items.description: Sets the `Transform` field `parent`.

params.name: parent
params.description: Transform to which the current Transform should be set as a child.

usage.code:
Transform transform = new Transform();
	transform.setParent(parent);

items.name: setParent

items.description: Transforms a `Vector3f` object using a matrix representation, returning the transformed position.

returns.description: a transformed position vector based on the parent matrix.

usage.code:
Vector3f myPos = new Vector3f();
myPos.set(1, 2, 3); // Set the position vector to (1, 2, 3)

Transform myTransform = new Transform(); // Create a new transform object
myTransform.setPos(myPos); // Set the position of the transform object to (1, 2, 3)

Vector3f transformedPos = myTransform.getTransformedPos(); // Get the transformed position vector
System.out.println(transformedPos); // Output: [2, 4, 6]

items.name: getTransformedPos

items.description: Takes a `Quaternion` object `parentRotation` and multiplies it with another `Quaternion` object `rot`, returning the transformed rotation.

returns.description: a Quaternion representation of the transformed rotation matrix multiplied by the input rotation matrix `rot`.

items.name: getTransformedRot

items.description: Returns a `Vector3f` object containing the position of an entity.

returns.description: a `Vector3f` object representing the position of the entity.

items.name: getPos

items.description: Sets the position of an object to a specified value.

params.name: pos
params.description: 3D position of an object or entity that the method is called on, and assigns it to the `pos` field of the class instance.

usage.description: In this example, we are creating a new instance of the Transform class and storing it in the variable "t". We then create a new vector of type Vector3f and store it in the variable "position". Finally, we use the setPos method to set the position value stored in variable "t" to be equal to the position value stored in variable "position".

items.name: setPos

items.description: Adds a vector to the position component of its object parameter, by first getting the current position and then adding the provided vector to it.

params.name: addVec
params.description: 3D vector to be added to the current position of the object, which is then updated using the `setPos()` method.

items.name: addToPos

items.description: Returns a `Quaternion` object representing the rotation of an entity.

returns.description: a Quaternion object representing the robot's rotation.

usage.description: In this example, we first create a new Transform object and set its position to (0, 0, 0) using the setPos() method. Then, we set its rotation to identity quaternion using the setRot() method. Next, we add (1, 0, 0) to its current position using the addToPos() method. Finally, we retrieve its rotation using getRot() and store it in a Quaternion object called "rotation".

items.name: getRot

items.description: Sets the instance field `rot` to the given `Quaternion` representation of a rotation matrix.

params.name: rotation
params.description: 4D quaternion that updates the rotational state of the object, which is stored in the `rot` field of the class.

items.name: setRot

items.description: Returns the object's scale value as a `Vector3f` instance.

returns.description: a `Vector3f` object representing the scale of the game object.

items.name: getScale

items.description: Sets the scale of an object, replacing its previous value.

params.name: scale
params.description: 3D scaling factor for the object, which is applied to its geometry.

items.name: setScale

items.description: Returns an empty string.

returns.description: an empty string.

items.name: toString

structured.description: A 3D graphics program using LWJGL, with a basic scene consisting of a camera, a shader, and a cube. The program also includes a world object for storing voxel data, but this is not explicitly accessed or used in the provided code. The main function initializes display and GL capabilities, loads a default shader, and renders the cube at the correct position and size. The update function processes input and updates the position of the camera, while the render function draws the cube using the shader and camera positions.

items.description: Has various methods for initializing and updating display and GPU state, rendering 3D graphics, and exiting the application. It also includes a Model class, a Shader class, a Texture class, and a World class, which are likely used for rendering 3D graphics.
items.name: Main

items.description: Initializes display and GL resources, enters an endless loop to render graphics, and then exits with a success code (0).

params.name: args
params.description: 1 or more command-line arguments passed to the `main` method when the program is launched, which are then ignored and not used in the program's execution.

items.name: main

items.description: Sets up a display mode, creates a Display object, enables vertical syncing, and prints the OpenGL version string.
items.name: initDisplay

items.description: Initializes a 3D graphics environment using OpenGL ES 2.0. It sets up a camera, loads a shader, creates a texture, and defines a cube-shaped chunk for rendering.
items.name: initGL

items.description: Updates and renders a graphical user interface using the Java 2D API, displaying the frame rate and memory usage in the title bar. It loops until the user requests closure or the escape key is pressed.
items.name: loop

items.description: Updates the position of an object (`w`) based on input from a controller (`c`) and its current transform state, using a fixed time step `dt`.

params.name: dt
params.description: time step passed to the `processInput()` method for processing.

items.name: update

items.description: Renders a 3D scene using the `GLSL` shader language. It sets up the rendering context, binds the modelview and projection matrices, and draws the 3D objects in the scene.
items.name: render

items.description: Terminates the Java process with the specified status code, which can be a value between 0 and 2147483647.

params.name: status
params.description: exit code for the program, which is passed to the `System.exit()` method to terminate the program.

items.name: exit
